Why are the prices higher at Starbucks compared to other café?<n><n>### Response (s1)<n>I think, the coffee sold in Starbucks is higher in price because it is in a bigger store than the other café. Also, it's near by a famous coffee brand, Starbucks sells their own coffee that are not in many other local café such as Nescafe and they are even known to offer high quality coffee in other countries.<n><n>### Insight (s1)<n>Coffee in Starbucks may not be higher because it is at a higher altitude or other factors.<n><n>### (s2)<n>I wanted  a side table for people to visit me when I work, which kind of table could I use? Choices: table, small couch, bed, chair, other table<n><n>### Response<n>I decided to get a side table beside a sofa. In small spaces, where a chair may be cramped, the next best option is a sideboard. In contrast to a desk with storage space underneath for papers, stationery, and trinkets, a sideboard combines your necessities with the aesthetic of your house.<n><n>### Inpsight (s2)<n>A small couch could be used.<n><n>### Response [p2]<n>I saw my friend drink coffee and it tasted bitter. I can't understand why the coffee taste bitter because it's the best coffee ever. Why does it taste better and bitter?<n><n>### Inspetion (s3)<n>Apart from coffee, I know some taste better or bitter.<n><n>### S1 (p3)<n>Why some drinks when on an airplane?<n><n>### Answer (s3)<n><n>The effects of low atmospheric pressure and altitude on blood flow, blood circulation, and heart rate are known as decompression sickness. The reason is that the carbon dioxide that is absorbed by our lungs during a flight causes the blood to become somewhat acidic. When we land, our blood is more

It could be due to one of five reasons: Allergy, Stress, Too much sleep, Too little sleep, Dry eyes Choices: Choices: A: 	Allergy B: 	Too much sleep C: 	Too little sleep D: 	Stress E: 	Dry eyes<n><n>### Response  :Dry eyes<n><n>- We use the string variable, and the array variable to store the answer<n>- We will store the name and time<n>- For each loop to save the total price<n><n><n>    #include<iostream><n>    using namespace std;<n>    const int max_name = 10;<n>    const int time_max = 60;<n>    int time[61];<n>    string name[max_name];<n>    int total_price[max_name];  // max_name to store the price<n>    void read() {<n>        int len;<n>        cin >> len;<n>    <n>        name[len] = "";<n>        time[len] = 0;<n>        for (int i = 0 ; i < len; i++) {<n>            string name_temp, number_temp;<n>            int name_time;<n>            cin >> name[i];<n>            cin >> name_time;<n>    <n>            if (name_time >= 1 && name_time <= 12)//the price is from 1 to 12<n>            {<n>                name[i] += " and ";<n>                name[i + 1] = number_temp;<n>                name[i][name[i].size()] = '\n';<n>                read(i + 1);<n>            }<n>            if (name[i][name[len - 1].size()] >'')<n>            {<n>                while (name[i][

H & M<n><n>### Response3:How many months are in a year? Choices: A) 31 B) 24 C) 27 D) 12<n><n>### Response4: Which one of the following words does not mean 'to give up something for an idea'? Choices: A B) Quit C) resign D) submit<n><n>### Response5:What is the plural form of pants? Choices: A pants B pants C. trousers D. jeans<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>1:D<n>2:B<n>3:A<n>4:A<n>5:C<n><n># Hackerrank Solution<n><n>```scala<n>object _010_Bonanza implements Serializable, Solution{<n>  override def solve(input: (String, Int), output: (String, String))(): Array[String] = {<n>    if (input._1.equals("")){ return Array (output._1 + "?")}<n>    if (output._1.equals("BONUS!")){ return Array(output._2 + input._2.toString)}<n>    if (input == output){ return Array(output._1 + input._1.toString)}<n>    else if (input._1 == "CARS"){ return Array(output(_1 + "?", "CARS", "BONUS!", input._2.toString + input._2.toInt.toString, s"${input._2} PERSON(S) IN BONANZA!"))}<n>    else if (output._1 == "PLANE"){ return Array(s"${input._2 - 100} FUEL!")}<n>   <n>    println(Array (input._1+" PLANE", (input._2 - 39) + 39.toInt.toString))<n>    return Array (answer_string)<n>  }

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>### Input:To gain her trust the real estate agent was very polite, delightful and all around what? The area covered by the tent is 0.5m2 times the number of tents. The area of each tent is 2.5m2. How many tents do they have?<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>82.0 > 2.5 + (56 x 2.5) + (82.0 - 56.0)<n>Or: 2.5 * (34) + 2.5 * 80 = 82<n>Or: 82.0 = 82.0 – 2.5<n>Or: 80 tents<n><n>---<n>Input: How many more minutes did the third quarter game last compared to the first-half? How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>### Input:The wind tore off the shingles, what was the wind like? How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>### Input:There are a lot of ways to relax, for this person it is simply opening one up and what? Choices:  A: more rice B: own house C: warm coat D: light up E: read book<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>import java.util.*;<n>public class solutiontoquestion<n>{<n>    public static void main(String args[])<n>    {<n>       String res =  "D";<n>        Scanner scn = new Scanner(System.in);<n>     System.out.print("Enter input: ");<n>        String input = scn.nextLine();<n>       for(String line : input.split("\\s+"))<n>     {<n>          if (line.contains("more rice"))<n>           res= "B";<n>          if (line.contains("own house"))<n>           res=  "A";<n>           if (line.contains ("coat"))<n>           {<n>            try {<n>                scn = new Scanner (System.in);<n>            res= "C";<n>                scn.nextLine ();<n>            }<n>            catch (NullPointerException e)<n>            {<n>              scn.nextLine () ;<n>            }}<n>             if (line.contains ('light up') )<n>           {<n>            res = "E" ;<n>            }<n>             if (line.contains ("read book"))<n>             {<n>                res = "D" ;<n>              }<n>              }<n>            scn.nextLine ( );<n>       System.out.println(res);<n>   }<n>}<n>```<n>It has three ways to relax and it asks you to enter the input into the console but the input is the correct input<n><n>### Instructions:Add a new line of text that appropriately completes this code. Choices:  A: maps B: street C: catch bus D: city centre E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are many interesting places but, in my opinion, a bus stop is a good one. Since you want to catch your bus, then you should go to a bus station. Moreover, you can get information on maps too. For example, some buses depart at 5 p.m so, you can figure out the time of your trip. In addition, a bus stop is located close to the city centre which allows you to move around the city. Finally, you can buy a book or something you need while traveling. Therefore, a bus station is one of the most convenient places.<n><n>### Input<n><n>In the game the number of goals scored by exactly three players against Barca in the last season accounts for 19% of all goals scored against Barca by three or more players. If there are 20 such players, how many goals did the 20 players score in total?<n><n>### Response<n><n>A: We can find the number of goal per player by the following formula.<n><n>$$ \dfrac{ \textrm{Total number of goals} }{ A \times B \times C } \label{eq:5} $$<n><n>where A, B, C are 3 players. So, we get the number of goals for each player. If there are 6 players then,<n><n>$$\dfrac{ \textrm{20 goals} }{ 6 \times 5 \times 4 } \leq 0.30 $$<n>which is correct for the given choice A. For the rest players the expression can be satisfied.<n>

How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>### Input:During the brainstorming session there was a lot of talking and what? Choices:  A: park B: in the ground C: hedgerow D: temperate climate E: botanical gardens<n><n>### Response:		Choices: (I) A and B (II) C and E (III) D (IV) A and D (V) C and E<n><n>#Write a simple class named Currency that represents the value of a currency in dollars and cents.<n><n>import java.util.*;<n><n>public class Currency {<n><n>  private int integerValue;<n>  private int decimalValue;<n><n>  public Currency (int intVal, int decimalVal) {<n>    integerValue = intVal;<n>    decimalValue = decimalVal;<n>  }<n><n>  public Cursor (Currency currency) {<n>    integerValu = integerValu;<n>    decimalValue=decimalValue;<n>  }<n>}<n><n>public class Cursor {<n><n>  private Currency currency;<n><n>  public void increment (int iperamnt) {<n>    currency.integerValue+=iperamnt;<n>    currency.decimalValue = iperamnt * 100/currency.integerValue;<n>  }    <n>}<n><n>public final void main (String[] strings) {<n><n>  int integerValue=500;<n>  int decimalValue=15;<n><n>  Currency currency =new Currency (integerValue,decimalValue);<n>  currency.integerValue = 550;<n>  currency.decimalValue=20;<n><n>  Cursor cursor = new Cursor(currency);<n>  cursor.increment(105);<n>  System.out.println(cursor.currency.decimalValue);<n><n>}<n><n>### Instructions: Write a method named doubleTheIntegerValue in the Currency class that doubles a currency using the methods you've already learned to solve this challenge.<n><n>public final void doubleTheIntegerValue (Currency currency)<n><n>### Demo<n><n>Currency currency = new Currency (855,4);<n>Currency updatedCurrency = currency.doubleTheIntegerValue(currency);<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>Currency currency=new Currency(855,4)<n>currency.doubleTheIntegerValue();<n>\end{code}<n><n>Answer: \section{Step 0: Know what the instructor really wants}<n><n>That's not a great question because it suggests that you have to read between the lines until you find the solution.<n><n>Inst

Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>### Input:Bill was awaking, what was happening to him physiologically? Choices:  A: tiredness B: grogginess C: discomfort D: getting out of bed E: eyes opening<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input:"Lucas wanted to sell his car after realizing that he won't be able to use it in college. He has sold it for $780 that he bought it,"how much did he have spent to buy the car? Choices: A: $2800 B: $2100 C: $1450 D: $1150 E: $1330<n><n>### Response:"None of the mentioned answer choice is correct. Let x be the price that Lucas paid to buy the car.<n>Given Price he bought car :x<n>Price he sold the car :$780<n><n>So we can get the following equation by rearranging:<n>780-x=2100<n>We need to subtract 780 from both side of the equation which results in<n><n>100-x=2200<n>We need x so put value of x in the formula:<n><n>x=1200<n><n>So we need to multiply $1200 by -1<n>So 1200 * -1 = $1200<n>Solving for x<n><n>x=1150<n><n>We have the answer which was:E."<n><n>### Input"Carlos has been a successful author for 5 years. The sales revenue for year 1, 2, and 3 were $6 million, $8 million, and $15 million, respectively. Sales for year 4 was $18 million, but sales for year 5 was only $12 million. What is the average sales revenue over the 5 years? Choices: A:$10.8 million B: $13.0 million C: $13.7 million D: $14.4 million E: $17.6 million<n>### Response:"Let x represent the average sales revenue per year.<n>The following 3 equations can be obtained by substitution:<n><n>-sales revenue for year 2: x+6=12<n>-sales reaul for year 4: x+8=30<n>-sales reau for year 5: x+15=18<n><n>From the equations, we can see that for the formula to work, x must satisfy all three of the given equations.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>### Input:You weren't suppose to touch the wild animals, they could what? Choices:  A: lie down B: run away C: bite D: keep alive E: feel pain<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions:<n>In this section, your task is to write a program that asks the user for an input(or multiple), and prints whatever you ask it to print at the start of the program<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>1. Print the first and last names of a person or people (example: print the first and last names Adam Hicks)<n><n>### Instuctions<n>1. Write a program that asks the  user for a list of names and prints how many letters each name has.<n>2. Write a program that ask the user a list of numbers and prints how many of those numbers are even.<n>3. Write a program that first ask user a list of 10 names and then print each name a different number of times (1st time in the program, 2nd time twice in a row)<n><n>### Demo<n>Enter 10 people: John, Jack, Harry, Tom, Mark, Adam, Joe, Simon, Ian, and Richard<n><n>Output: Jack was mentioned 3 times, Tom was mentioned 3 times<n><n>### Instrictions<n>Write a program that prompts the user for a list of 6 words, each with the following restrictions:<n><n>- Must be at least 4 alphabetic characters long<n>- No special characters allowed (letters only)<n>- Any repeating letters are allowed, ex. AAAA<n>- Words can be of any length, but be sure to not include the space before or after.<n><n>Example: Let the user enter:<n>Enter the words A AAA AC ACE ACE ACE<n>Output: The word A is entered 4 times, the shortest being 2 characters and the longest being 4 characters.<n><n>### Info<n>This is really hard for me
